author: Salman Khan
title: Liberty Bank and Ruth's House Team Up to Combat Elderly Scams in Longmeadow, Mass
text:
In an impactful community outreach event, Liberty Bank's Community Outreach Office partnered with Ruth's House in Longmeadow, Massachusetts, aiming to arm local residents and their families with critical information on identifying and preventing elderly scams. The collaboration brought together experts and community members in a shared effort to safeguard one of the most vulnerable segments of the population against financial fraud.
Educational Outreach: A Beacon of Hope
Mary-Anne Schelb, the Regional Director of Business Development, engaged with the attendees, highlighting the imperative need for elderly individuals to communicate suspicious activities to trusted family members, friends, or caretakers. In instances where seniors may find themselves isolated, Schelb emphasized the importance of reaching out to professionals within their living community or trusted financial institutions for guidance and support. The event also featured Dawn Creighton, Liberty Bank's Community Outreach Officer, who shared invaluable advice on recognizing common scam tactics, particularly those involving impostors posing as family members in distress.
Building Strong Defenses Against Scams
The initiative by Liberty Bank and Ruth's House underscores a critical approach towards combating elder fraud - education and open dialogue. Drawing on resources like Protecting Elderly Parent's Assets and Shield & Shine, the event provided attendees with a comprehensive toolkit for scam prevention. These resources advocate for initiating conversations about financial management, securing personal information, and employing technology such as call blockers and multi-factor authentication to deter scammers effectively.
Community Solidarity in Action
The collaborative effort between Liberty Bank and Ruth's House not only served as an educational forum but also as a testament to the power of community solidarity in facing societal challenges. By bringing these issues to the forefront and equipping individuals with the knowledge to protect themselves and their loved ones, such initiatives play a crucial role in mitigating the risks posed by financial scammers targeting the elderly.
As society continues to navigate through the complexities of financial security in the digital age, the union of community organizations, financial institutions, and individuals in such educational endeavors represents a beacon of hope and resilience. It reinforces the collective responsibility to shield our elders from the perils of scams, ensuring their dignity, security, and well-being remain intact.
